segments.text: When I came home to West Egg that night I was afraid for a moment that my house was on fire. Two o’clock and the whole corner of the peninsula was blazing with light that fell unreal on the shrubbery and made thin, elongating glints upon the roadside wires. Turning a corner, I saw that it was Gatsby’s house – lit from tower to cellar. For a fleeting moment I suspected a wild party was underway, but there wasn’t a sound – only the wind whispering in the trees and making the lights wink in and out of darkness. As my taxi groaned away, I caught sight of Gatsby walking toward me across his lawn.

segments.text: As evening fell and the last strains of piano – played by the reluctant Mr. Klipspringer – echoed through the music-room, the world outside shifted once more. The dull rumble of the rain, the interplay of light in West Egg, and a sense of profound, irreversible change filled the air. I took my leave, watching with a mix of awe and melancholy as Gatsby and Daisy remained together, bathed in the tumult of their own dreams. Their final exchange, a tender, almost imperceptible moment of connection, lingered with the intensity of a deathless song.
